selected_quotes: Macaque Social Responsiveness Scale (mSRS): A Screening Tool for Assessing Variability in Social Responsiveness
Macaque social responsiveness scale: a rapid screening tool for assessing variability
First the chimp SRS, now the macaque SRS? To the best of our knowledge, animals do not develop a…
The Macaque Social Responsiveness Scale (mSRS). This mimics a scale used to diagnose and grade #autism in humans

citation.abstract: Understanding the biological mechanisms underlying human neuropsychiatric disorders, such as autism spectrum disorder (ASD), has been hindered by the lack of a robust, translational animal model. Rhesus monkeys (Macaca mulatta) display many of the same social behaviors that are affected in ASD, making them an excellent animal species in which to model social impairments. However, the social impairments associated with ASD may reflect extreme ends of a continuous distribution of traits. Thus, to validate the rhesus monkey as an animal model for studying social impairments that has strong translational relevance for ASD, researchers need an easily-implemented measurement tool that can quantify variation in social behavior dimensionally. The Social Responsiveness Scale (SRS) is a 65-item survey that identifies both typical and atypical social behaviors in humans that covary with ASD symptom severity. A chimpanzee SRS has already been validated and the current study adapted this tool for use in the rhesus monkey (mSRS). Fifteen raters completed the mSRS for 105 rhesus monkeys living at the Yerkes National Primate Research Center. The mSRS scores showed a unimodal distribution with a positive skew that identified 6 statistical outliers. Inter-rater reliability was very strong, but only 17 of the 36 questions showed positive intra-item reliability. The results of an exploratory factor analysis identified 3 factors that explained over 60% of the variance, with 12 items significantly loading onto the primary factor. These items reflected behaviors associated with social avoidance, social anxiety or inflexibility and social confidence. These initial findings are encouraging and suggest that variability in the social responsiveness of rhesus monkeys can be quantified using the mSRS: a tool that has strong translational relevance for human disorders. With further modification, the mSRS may provide an promising new direction for research on the biological mechanisms underlying social impairments.
citation.title: The Macaque Social Responsiveness Scale (mSRS): A Rapid Screening Tool for Assessing Variability in the Social Responsiveness of Rhesus Monkeys (Macaca mulatta).

author.name: マーキュリー２世
author.description: 少なくとも大学初年次までは場面緘黙症（自己診断）だった男。Twitterまとめ(http://psychobrain.seesaa.net/)。 注意事項①論文は要約しか読んでいない場合が多い②間違っている可能性あり③私は研究者ではない。

author.name: 概念主義者 ニートリアージ 我輩は猫以下
author.description: 概念放浪者　2017年　心　縄を恨む泥棒　2014年4月　自戒　瓜田李下　眼高手低　ジーン・レイヴ　シグニファイア　オカルト好きの不可知論者　ブライト　ミーム　コスモポリタニズム　たまたま　無知のヴェール　自由についての前提覆水盆にもカエル制約なし　犬儒学派　徒然草　ヤノマミ　ピダハン　辟易　発達障害　アフォーダンス

author.name: Liz Simpson
author.description: Assistant Professor of Psychology at the University of Miami. Research interests: infancy, evolution, development, social cognition, face perception.

author.name: Lauren Brent
author.description: Social networks and the evolution of social relationships. Leverhulme Early Career Fellow and Lecturer in Animal Behaviour at the University of Exeter.
